results.title: L'argent des Autres = Other People's Money
results.creator_credit: Christian de Chalonge, Adolphe Viezzi, Henri Lassa and Michelle de Broca
results.brief_description:
Henri Rainier, a bank director, is unwillingly implicated in a financial fraud and laid off. Convinced he is being set up by others in the bank, he decides to investigate a number of dubious transactions and discovers a vast real estate swindle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc, 1978 ; French Academy of Cinema (Cesars) 1978: Best Director for Christian de Chalonge, Best Film.

Credits: Producers, Michelle de Broca, Henri Lassa, Adolphe Viezzi ; director, Christian de Chalonge ; writers, Pierre Dumayet, Christian de Chalonge ; photography, Jean-Louis Picavet ; music, Patrice Mestral.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Claude Brasseur, Michel Serrault, Catherine Deneuve, Juliet Berto, Francois Perrot.

results.title: L'Ange
results.creator_credit: Patrick Bokanowski, INA France and Kira BM Films
results.brief_description: This amazing marriage of art, music and film took five years (1977-1982) in the making by its French creator, Patrick Bokanowski and programmed non-stop in a Tokyo cinema for nearly ten years. The impressionistic images are accompanied by a beautiful atmospheric soundtrack of original music composed by Michele Bokanowski to present a textured, multi-layered complexity of vision and sound. “L’Ange” makes for compelling viewing and deserves its cult status in the world of avant-garde filmmaking. Cast includes Jacques Faure, Martine Couture, Jean-Marie Bon, Dominique Lesourd, Maurice Baquet, Rita Renoir, Patricia Peretti.

results.title: L'age En Fleur = the Blossoming Years
results.brief_description:
This teen drama set in a ballet school in Nice deals with the personal rivalries between dancers for the part of Galatea as well as the love entanglements between dancers and teachers.

Cast: Marcelline Collard, Manuel Bonnet, Maina Gielgud, Attilio Labis.

results.title: L'age D'or du Film Muet (1915-1928) Pt. 13
results.brief_description:
Part 13 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. This episode profiles the ‘Golden age of silent film’ and the incursion of Avant-Garde and Art Deco aesthetics in feature films. During WWI, European cinema (and particularly the houses of Gaumont, Pathe and L’Eclair) endures a reversal of fortune under both the economic and stylistic pressure of the USA. Melies has sold his studio, star Max Linder is seeking fortune in the USA. French cinema is stagnant and unable to extract itself from the theatrical stylistics of the ‘film d’art’ (literary adaptations), while the U.S. are holding audiences captive with weekly deliveries of adventure and comic serials. During the Roaring Twenties, French cinema renews itself entirely through its first avant-garde movement (expressionism) and second avant-garde (surrealism). Influenced by D.W. Griffiths’ ‘Broken Blossoms’(1919), Delluc sought in his own films to convey, through editing, the motions of human psychology, and to this end developed the flashback technique in ‘La femme de nulle part’ (1922). The innovations in film technique which resulted from impressionists’ desire to evoke human subjectivity included close-ups, camera movements, rapid editing, flashbacks and subjective point-of-view shots. Marcel L’Herbier ‘El Dorado’ (1921) features ‘semi-subjective’ sequences to express a character’s psychological state. Rhythmic cutting to express a drunken or unstable state of mind, first evident in Abel Gance’s ‘La roue’ (1922) and subsequently in Jean Epstein’s ‘Coeur fidele’ (1923) was perhaps the technique most linked to the movement.” (1) Influenced by the Avant-Garde and the Art Deco style, Marcel L’Herbier directs two major projects in the 1920s: ‘L’inhumaine’ (1924), starring Brigitte Helm, for which he assembled the most brilliant artists of his time: Robert Mallet-Stevens, Fernand Leger, Paul Poiret, Darius Milhaud; and ‘L’argent’ (1929)[NLA #0678050] in which L’Herbier directs fascinating experiments with camera mobility. This episode profiles ‘Crainquebille’ (1923), directed by Jacques Feyder, a dramatic tale set in popular Paris and prefiguring ‘Poetic realism’. Also featured, Abel Gance’s early science-fiction serials ‘La folie du Docteur Tube’ (1915) [NLA #2108421], ‘La roue’ and his anti-war film ‘J’accuse’(1937). Reference: (1) Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema’. Manchester University Press, 1996. Further reading: Richard Abel. “French cinema: the first wave, 1915-1929”. Princeton University Press, 1984. N.b. Best viewed as part 2 of the series.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Cassard.
Interviewees include: Abel Gance, Marcel L’Herbier, Rene Clair, Jacques Feyder.

results.title: L'africaine
results.creator_credit: Lotfi Mansouri, Robert Walker, KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.), RM Arts and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: L’Africaine, recorded live from the San Francisco Opera, is conducted by Maurizio Arena. The story tells how Vasco da Gama sails to find a new land beyond Africa and is shipwrecked on the African coast. He returns to Portugal with two captives Nelsuko and Selika. He has fallen in love with Selika but she finally sacrifices her life so that da Gama can marry his former love, Ines. Music by Giocomo Meyerbeer. Stars Shirley Verrett and Placido Domingo.

results.title: L'acrobate = the Acrobat
results.creator_credit: Jean-Daniel Pollet, Ilios Films and Les Films du Chef-Lieu
results.brief_description:
Leon, an often bullied bathhouse attendant, is too timid to get a date and must often share his nights and dreams with the local working girls. He is truly in love with one of them and does not quite know how to declare his passion. Leon decides to take up tango lesson. As Leon’s footwork improves on the dance floor, so does his ability to approach women. Awards: Prix de la Critique. Festival du Film d’Humour, Chamrousse 1976

Credits: Director, Jean-Daniel Pollet ; writers, Jean-Daniel Pollet, Jacques Lourcelles.
Cast: Claude Melki, Guy Marchand, Marion Game, Micheline Dax, Laurence Bru, Edith Scob.

results.title: L' imagination et le Front Populaire Au Pourvoir (1935-1936) Pt. 4
results.brief_description:
Part 4 of a 13 part series on the history of French cinema. By the mid-thirties, French cinema is enjoying a phase of expansion. Surprisingly, the influx of German personnel fleeing the Nazi regime helps expanding the market for French cinema into Eastern Europe. This is the time during which Pommer leaves UFA to work in Paris to produce ‘Liliom’ with Fritz Lang. An other emigre is Pabst who directs ‘The Three Penny Opera’ and ‘L’Atlantide’, starring Brigitte Helm. Alexander Korda, brought to France by Pagnol to direct ‘Marius’ also directs ‘La dame de chez Maxim’s’, before returning to the UK. For most of the German emigres such as Billy Wilder, Robert Siodmak, Anatole Litvak, Fritz lang, G. W. Pabst, France was only a stop over on their way to real careers and prospects in Hollywood. It must also be noted that certain members of the French film industry did go out of their way to make them feel rather unwelcome. This nationalist animosity is best expressed in a revealing interview with Claude Autant-Lara. These few years are the golden age of commercial production: producers make safe bets with adaptations of theatrical success, bordering on the Vaudeville, and using to great effect the strong presence of character actors, such as Fernandel, Raimu, Larquey, etc … Distraught at the arrival of sound, French cinema seems to have opted for an increasing banality. After the flop of ‘The last millionaire’, Rene Clair is off to England and the USA and won’t return to France for an other 10 years. Renoir directs ‘La vie est a nous’ , ‘Le crime de Monsieur Lange’ and ‘Une partie de campagne’. The greatest novelty for the period is a short film directed by an unknown Jacques Prevert: ‘L’affaire est dans le sac’. The film seems to herald something new: the come-back of poetry in film. Shortly after, Carne, formerly an assistant to Jacques Feyder, directs his first film ‘Jenny’ and opens the way to a fruitful collaboration with Prevert. A good example of the new mood in cinema and an iconic film of the ‘Front Populaire’ is Duvivier’s ‘La Belle Equipe’. =Held in our collection.

Credits: Director, Armand Panigel ; photography, Claude Casard.
Interviewees include: Rene Clair, Pierre Braunberger, Marcel L’Herbier, Yves Allegret, Henri-George Clouzot, Claude Autant-Lara, Raoul Ploquin, Charles Spaak, Marcel Carne, Pierre Billon, Jean-Paul Le Chanois.

results.title: Kyushu: Japan's island of wonders
results.creator_credit: Iwanami Productions and Japan. National Tourist Organisation
results.brief_description: Travelogue on Kyushu, the southern-most of Japan’s four main islands. While drawing brief attention to Japan’s expanding industrial capacity and intensive agricultural practices, the film is designed with the purpose of encouraging western tourists. Thus, it catalogues a wealth of familiar recreational pursuits, eg golf; the medicinal benefits of the numerous thermal springs and the exotic charm of Hakkata porcelain.

results.title: Kyoto: ancient capital of Japan
results.creator_credit: Iwanami Productions and Japan. National Tourist Organisation
results.brief_description: Shows the city of Kyoto, built when Japan was under the greatest influence of China. From 1794 to 1868 it was the capital city of Japan, and today is the 1100 years old cradle of Japanese art, science and culture - a city of temples, palaces and universities and the centre for research in physics, philosophy and oriental studies. It is renowned for ceramic handicrafts, porcelain, modern Japanese painting, silk weaving and beautiful brocades.
